items.title: Romania summons Russian ambassador after drone breaches country's airspace
items.standfirst: Romania summoned the Russian ambassador to Bucharest on Sunday after a drone was observed breaching the country's airspace on its way to strike targets in Ukraine on Saturday. Poland also scrambled fighter jets last week to shoot down a number of Russian drones that had entered its airspace.
items.content: Romania summoned the Russian ambassador to Bucharest on Sunday after a drone was observed breaching the country's airspace on its way to strike targets in Ukraine on Saturday. Poland also scrambled fighter jets last week to shoot down a number of Russian drones that had entered its airspace.

items.title: 9/10: CBS Mornings Plus
items.standfirst: Poland says it shot down Russian drones during attack on Ukraine. Also, why no storms are forming during the peak of Atlantic hurricane season.
items.content: Poland says it shot down Russian drones during attack on Ukraine. Also, why no storms are forming during the peak of Atlantic hurricane season.

items.title: Russian drone incursion into Poland ‘was Kremlin test on Nato’
items.standfirst: Polish minister says Moscow sought to gauge reaction without starting war as Romania reports new incursionPoland’s foreign minister has said the Russian drone incursion into Polish airspace was an attempt by the Kremlin to test Nato’s reactions by incremental escalations without prompting a full-scale response, as Romania became the second Nato country to report an incursion in a matter of days.Radosław Sikorski confirmed that while the drones that entered Poland last week were capable of carrying ammunition, they were not loaded with explosives. “Interestingly, they were all duds, which suggests to me that Russia tried to test us without starting a war,” Sikorski told the Guardian in Kyiv. Continue reading...
items.content: Polish minister says Moscow sought to gauge reaction without starting war as Romania reports new incursionPoland’s foreign minister has said the Russian drone incursion into Polish airspace was an attempt by the Kremlin to test Nato’s reactions by incremental escalations without prompting a full-scale response, as Romania became the second Nato country to report an incursion in a matter of days.Radosław Sikorski confirmed that while the drones that entered Poland last week were capable of carrying ammunition, they were not loaded with explosives. “Interestingly, they were all duds, which suggests to me that Russia tried to test us without starting a war,” Sikorski told the Guardian in Kyiv. Continue reading...

items.title: Romania says Russian drone incursions pose ‘new challenge’ to Black Sea security
items.standfirst: Country’s defence ministry condemns ‘irresponsible actions’ after drone entered its airspace on SaturdaySee all our Ukraine war coverageRomania has strongly condemned the entry of a Russian drone into its airspace during an attack on neighbouring Ukraine, saying Moscow’s actions pose a “new challenge” to Black Sea security.Poland had already denounced the intrusion of Russian drones into its airspace last week, calling on Moscow to avoid further “provocations”. Polish fighter jets scrambled on Saturday in response to fresh Russian drone strikes just over the border in Ukraine. Continue reading...
items.content: Country’s defence ministry condemns ‘irresponsible actions’ after drone entered its airspace on SaturdaySee all our Ukraine war coverageRomania has strongly condemned the entry of a Russian drone into its airspace during an attack on neighbouring Ukraine, saying Moscow’s actions pose a “new challenge” to Black Sea security.Poland had already denounced the intrusion of Russian drones into its airspace last week, calling on Moscow to avoid further “provocations”. Polish fighter jets scrambled on Saturday in response to fresh Russian drone strikes just over the border in Ukraine. Continue reading...

items.title: America now in an era of "violent populism," says University of Chicago professor Robert Pape
items.standfirst: Robert Pape, University of Chicago professor and founding director of the Chicago Project on Security and Threats, told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that he believes the U.S. is in an era of "violent populism," which he says can be defined by the rise in political violence from both the right and the left and increased support for political violence.
items.content: Robert Pape, University of Chicago professor and founding director of the Chicago Project on Security and Threats, told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that he believes the U.S. is in an era of "violent populism," which he says can be defined by the rise in political violence from both the right and the left and increased support for political violence.

items.title: Sen. Chris Coons says the internet is "driving extremism in this country"
items.standfirst: As the nation grapples with the fallout from the Charlie Kirk assassination last week, Sens. James Lankford, Republican of Oklahoma, and Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, join "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" to discuss how Congress can model civility. Coons warns that the idea that Kirk could be killed "in such a grotesque and public way has to bring us to reflect about how hard it's getting, because the internet is an accelerant – it is driving extremism in this country."
items.content: As the nation grapples with the fallout from the Charlie Kirk assassination last week, Sens. James Lankford, Republican of Oklahoma, and Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, join "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" to discuss how Congress can model civility. Coons warns that the idea that Kirk could be killed "in such a grotesque and public way has to bring us to reflect about how hard it's getting, because the internet is an accelerant – it is driving extremism in this country."

clusters.title: Final stage of Spain's Vuelta abandoned after police clash with pro-Palestinian protesters
clusters.neutral_headline: Vuelta Cycling Race Final Stage Abandoned Due to Protests

items.title: Final stage of Spain's Vuelta abandoned after police clash with pro-Palestinian protesters
items.standfirst: The final stage of Spain's Vuelta cycling race was abandoned on Sunday afternoon as cyclists were entering Madrid after police clashed with pro-Palestinian protesters in the Spanish capital's centre. Police fired tear gas at the crowds as hundreds of pro-Palestinian protesters knocked down security barriers and surged onto the course.
items.content: The final stage of Spain's Vuelta cycling race was abandoned on Sunday afternoon as cyclists were entering Madrid after police clashed with pro-Palestinian protesters in the Spanish capital's centre. Police fired tear gas at the crowds as hundreds of pro-Palestinian protesters knocked down security barriers and surged onto the course.

clusters.title: Trump Urges European Allies to Slap Tariffs on China for Russian Oil Purchases
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Urges NATO Allies to Impose Tariffs on China

items.title: Trump Urges European Allies to Slap Tariffs on China for Russian Oil Purchases
Trump calls on NATO members to stop purchasing Russian oil
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said Saturday he believes the Russia-Ukraine war would end if all NATO countries stopped buying oil from Russia and placed tariffs on China of 50 percent to 100 percent for its purchases of Russian petroleum. Since 2023, NATO member Turkey has been the third largest buyer of Russian oil, after China and India.
items.content: President Donald Trump said Saturday he believes the Russia-Ukraine war would end if all NATO countries stopped buying oil from Russia and placed tariffs on China of 50 percent to 100 percent for its purchases of Russian petroleum. Since 2023, NATO member Turkey has been the third largest buyer of Russian oil, after China and India.

items.title: Trump urges NATO countries to stop 'shocking' Russian oil purchases
items.standfirst: The war in Ukraine would end if all NATO countries stopped buying oil from Russia, Donald Trump has said.
items.content: The war in Ukraine would end if all NATO countries stopped buying oil from Russia, Donald Trump has said.

ai_summary: Trump urged European allies to impose tariffs on China for Russian oil purchases.
Trump believes the war in Ukraine would end if NATO stopped buying Russian oil.
Trump also suggested imposing tariffs of 50-100% on China for oil purchases.
Since 2023, Turkey has been the third-largest buyer of Russian oil.
Trump said NATO countries should stop "shocking" Russian oil purchases.

clusters.title: Delta Pilots Suspended Over Social Media Posts on Charlie Kirk Assassination
clusters.neutral_headline: Delta Pilots Suspended Over Social Media Posts on Charlie Kirk Assassination

items.title: Delta Pilots Suspended Over Social Media Posts on Charlie Kirk Assassination
Political leaders confront security concerns — and fear — after Kirk's assassination
What to know about the aftermath of Charlie Kirk’s assassination
‘A uniquely dangerous time?’: The aftermath of Charlie Kirk's killing | The Conversation
items.standfirst: POLITICO's Global Editor-In-Chief John Harris joins The Conversation to discuss Charlie Kirk's death.
items.content: In the aftermath of the killing of conservative organizer Charlie Kirk, Politico’s Global Editor-In-Chief John Harris observes that there are few, if any, national figures who are spreading a message of unity. We’re at a point, he says, “where almost every news event very quickly does become politicized, and people view events as … weapons or shields in a nonstop political argument.” Kirk, 31, was shot and killed while he was speaking at an event at Utah Valley University. Kirk was among the nation’s most prominent conservative organizers, founding Turning Point USA when he was just 18 years old and growing it into a nationwide youth movement with hundreds of chapters. Harris joined POLITICO’s Dasha Burns to discuss Kirk and the impact of his life and death on American politics in the latest episode of “The Conversation.” “He was a larger-than-life figure in Republican politics,” Burns said, describing him as “controversial” and “provocative” but noting his commitment to debate. “I interviewed Charlie multiple times and our exchanges were sometimes intense. I pressed him, he pushed back, but in the end he was always cordial. Always willing to engage,” she said. His killing is the latest in a string of acts of political violence — from the attempted assassination of then-candidate Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania, last summer to the killing of Melissa Hortman, the former Democratic speaker of the Minnesota house, and her husband in June. Harris notes that while there have been periods of violence in America — the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995, among others — in the past, national leaders have at least sought to share messages of unity in the aftermath. While the current political moment has taken us away from that messaging, Harris notes that our climate of divisiveness is out of step with the majority of Americans. “I think a lot of people do wish for something better," he said, "I would think almost every person wishes for something different than the horrific violence that we saw.” The full interview with Harris is available this weekend on The Conversation wherever you get your podcasts.

items.title: 'A uniquely dangerous time?': The aftermath of Charlie Kirk's killing | The Conversation
items.content: 'A uniquely dangerous time?': The aftermath of Charlie Kirk's killing | The Conversation lead image
